	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.78PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Note:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	(1)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Revenues and costs of sales and services for these years have been reclassified to present certain transactions on a net basis. This had no impact on our net income from operations, net income, cash flow statements or financial position for such years. Please see &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Item 5: Operating and Financial Review and Prospects &#8211; Prior Periods
</FONT>
	&#8221; for further information.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, our proportionate revenues by product were: (i) 18% steel products; (ii)&nbsp;42% minerals, chemicals and alloys; (iii) 10% metals; (iv)&nbsp;23% wood products; and (v) 7% other. In 2014, 68% of our revenues were from Europe, 22% were from the Americas and 10% were from Asia and other regions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Based upon the yearly average exchange rates for 2014, the Canadian dollar decreased by approximately 7% in value against each of the Euro and the United States dollar, compared to the average exchange rates in 2013. As at December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Canadian dollar had strengthened by approximately 4% against the Euro and had weakened by approximately 8% against the United States dollar since December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Revenues in 2014 increased to $1,286.3 million from $621.1 million in 2013, primarily as a result of organic growth in certain product lines and an overall increase in finance and supply chain revenue (see below) due to the consolidation of our acquisitions in the second quarter of 2014. As a substantial portion of our revenues were generated in Euros, the strengthening of the Euro against the Canadian dollar positively impacted our results of operations for 2014.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	29
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Revenues for our finance and supply chain business were $1,256.5 million in 2014, compared to $597.5 million in 2013, primarily as a result of organic growth in certain product lines, the consolidation of our acquisitions in the second quarter of 2014 and the impact of the stronger Euro against the Canadian dollar.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Revenues for our all other segments were $29.8 million in 2014, compared to $23.6 million in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Costs of sales and services increased to $1,178.0 million in 2014 from $550.8 million in 2013, primarily as a result of the consolidation of our acquisitions in the second quarter of 2014 and the impact of the stronger Euro against the Canadian dollar. The following is a breakdown of our costs of sales and services for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_26"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:414.55PT;HEIGHT:168.5PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:8PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">
<TR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;VERTICAL-ALIGN:BOTTOM;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF;PADDING:0PT 0PT 0.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:288.47PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;PADDING:0PT 0PT 2.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:0PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;" COLSPAN="10">
<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	Years Ended December&nbsp;31,
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:0PT;">
	&#8203;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.97PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Note:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	(1)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Revenues and costs of sales and services for these years have been reclassified to present certain transactions on a net basis. This had no impact on our net income from operations, net income, cash flow statements or financial position for such years. Please see &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Item 5: Operating and Financial Review and Prospects &#8211; Prior Periods
</FONT>
	&#8221; for further information.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, the gain on derivative contracts of&#8201; $3.5 million primarily resulted from commodity and currency derivatives.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses, excluding share-based compensation, increased to $81.5 million in 2014 from $53.8 million in 2013. The increase was primarily as a result of our acquisitions in the second quarter of 2014, expansion to new geographies and markets, certain restructuring and severance expenses and the impact of the stronger Euro against the Canadian dollar.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	During 2014, finance costs increased to $13.3 million from $9.7 million in 2013 as a result of increased borrowings in our supply chain business.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, we recognized $0.4 million of share-based compensation expense as a result of the granting of stock options to employees during the year, compared to $nil in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Impairment of available-for-sale securities was $0.3 million in 2014, compared to $0.6 million in 2013. This represented an other-than-temporary decline in the value of our investment portfolio.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, we recognized a net foreign currency transaction loss of&#8201; $6.3 million, compared to $2.2 million in 2013, in the consolidated statement of operations. The loss in 2014 was primarily non-cash and relates to the settlement of certain intercompany accounts of subsidiaries with different functional currencies in pursuit of fiscally responsible strategies. To a lesser extent, we recognized a net currency translation loss on monetary assets and liabilities of subsidiaries which were denominated in currencies other than their functional currencies.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We recognized an income tax expense of&#8201; $2.2 million in 2014, compared to a recovery of&#8201; $1.0 million in 2013. Our statutory tax rate was 26.0% in 2014, compared to 25.75% in 2013, and our effective tax rates were lower than our statutory tax rates in 2014. The income tax paid in cash during 2014 was $4.2 million, compared to $2.3 million in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, our net income attributable to shareholders from continuing operations was $2.8 million, or $0.04 per share on a basic and diluted basis, compared to net income attributable to shareholders from continuing operations of&#8201; $4.3 million, or $0.07 per share on a basic and diluted basis, in 2013.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	30
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
<A NAME="T1600851-20F_HTM_TI5LCR">
	&#8203;
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our revenues from discontinued operations were $146.7 million for 2014, compared to $128.2 million for 2013. The increase was primarily the result of higher natural gas pricing.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, our loss from discontinued operations was $3.5 million, or $0.05 per share on a basic and diluted basis, which included a non-cash impairment on our hydrocarbon properties of&#8201; $33.2 million, or $0.53 per share on a basic and diluted basis, before income taxes, compared to net income from discontinued operations of&#8201; $5.4 million, or $0.09 per share, for 2013, which included a non-cash impairment loss on our hydrocarbon properties of&#8201; $6.5 million, or $0.10 per share on a basic and diluted basis, before income taxes. Please see Note 4 to our audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 for further information.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, our net loss attributable to shareholders was $0.7 million, or $0.01 per share on a basic and diluted basis, after giving effect to a non-cash impairment loss on hydrocarbon properties of&#8201; $33.2 million, or $0.53 per share on a basic and diluted basis, before income taxes, compared to net income attributable to shareholders of&#8201; $9.7 million, or $0.16 per share on a basic and diluted basis, in 2013 after giving effect to a non-cash impairment loss on hydrocarbon properties of&#8201; $6.5 million, or $0.10 per share on a basic and diluted basis, before income taxes.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In 2014, our Operating EBITDA from continuing operations increased by approximately 62% to $24.5 million, or $0.39 per share on a basic and diluted basis, from $15.1 million, or $0.24 per share on a basic and diluted basis, in 2013. Operating EBITDA from continuing operations is defined as earnings from continuing operations before interest, taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and impairment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Operating EBITDA from continuing operations is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results as reported under IFRS.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The following is a reconciliation of our net income to Operating EBITDA from continuing operations for each of the years indicated.
</DIV>

	Note:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">

	Please see &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Non-IFRS Financial Measures
</FONT>
	&#8221; for additional information.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	General
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Liquidity is of importance to our business as insufficient liquidity often results in underperformance.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our objectives when managing capital are:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	to safeguard our ability to continue as a going concern so that we can continue to provide returns for shareholders and benefits for other stakeholders;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	to provide an adequate return to our shareholders by pricing products and services commensurately with the level of risk; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	to maintain a flexible capital structure that optimizes the cost of capital at acceptable risk.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We set the amount of capital in proportion to risk. We manage our capital structure and make adjustments to it in the light of changes in economic conditions and the risk characteristics of the underlying assets. In order to maintain or adjust this capital structure, we may adjust the amount of dividends paid to shareholders, return capital to shareholders, issue new shares or sell assets to reduce debt.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	31
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Consistent with others in our industry, we monitor capital on the basis of our net debt-to-equity ratio and long-term debt-to-equity ratio. The net debt-to-equity ratio is calculated as net debt divided by shareholders&#8217; equity. Net debt is calculated as total debt less cash and cash equivalents. The long-term debt-to-equity ratio is calculated as long-term debt divided by shareholders&#8217; equity. The computations are based on continuing operations.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The following table sets forth the calculation of our net debt-to-equity ratio as at the dates indicated:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_28"></A>

<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP; TEXT-ALIGN:RIGHT;">
	Not applicable&#8203;
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16.99PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	There were no amounts in accumulated other comprehensive income relating to cash flow hedges, nor were there any subordinated debt instruments as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013. Our net debt-to-equity ratio as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 was 0.17 and 0.02, respectively, and as at December&nbsp;31, 2013 was not applicable, as we had net cash and cash equivalents balances.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	During 2015, our strategy, which remained unchanged from 2014 and 2013, was to maintain our net debt-to-equity ratio and long-term debt-to-equity ratio at manageable levels. Our long-term debt-to-equity ratio was 0.47, 0.38 and 0.27 as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Cash Flows
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Due to the number of businesses we engage in, our cash flows are not necessarily reflective of net earnings and net assets for any reporting period. As a result, instead of using a traditional cash flow analysis solely based on cash flow statements, our management believes it is more useful and meaningful to analyze our cash flows by overall liquidity and credit availability. Please see the discussion on our financial position, short-term bank loans, facilities and long-term debt below.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The finance and supply chain business can be cyclical and our cash flows vary accordingly. Our principal operating cash expenditures are for our working capital, proprietary investments and general and administrative expenses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Working capital levels fluctuate throughout the year and are affected by the level of our finance and supply chain operations, the markets and prices for commodities and the timing of receivables and the payment of payables and expenses. Changes in the volume of transactions can affect the level of receivables and influence overall working capital levels. We currently have a sufficient level of cash on hand and credit facility amounts and we believe that we have sufficient cash flows from operations, cash on hand and credit availability to meet our working capital and other requirements as well as unexpected cash demands.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	32
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:20PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;">
</FONT>
	Cash Flows from Continuing Operating Activities
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Operating activities used cash of&#8201; $94.1 million in 2015, compared to $48.6 million in 2014. In 2015, a decrease in short-term bank borrowings used cash of&#8201; $135.5 million, compared to $99.3 million in 2014. A decrease in receivables (including derivative assets) provided cash of&#8201; $56.3 million in 2015, compared to $3.6 million in 2014, primarily as a result of collections of trade receivables. A decrease in account payables and accrued expenses (including derivative liabilities) used cash of&#8201; $17.0 million in 2015, compared to an increase in account payables and accrued expenses providing cash of&#8201; $13.4 million in 2014. A decrease in inventories provided cash of&#8201; $15.7 million in 2015, compared to an increase in inventories using cash of $32.0 million in 2014. An increase in deposits, pre-paid and other, used cash of&#8201; $8.6 million in 2015, compared to a decrease in deposits, pre-paid and other, providing cash of&#8201; $41.4 million in 2014. The increase in deposits, pre-paid and other, was primarily a result of an increase in prepaid inventories.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Operating activities used cash of&#8201; $48.6 million in 2014, compared to $27.5 million in 2013. In 2014, a decrease in short-term bank borrowings used cash of&#8201; $99.3 million, compared to $32.6 million in 2013. A decrease in deposits, prepaid and other provided cash of&#8201; $41.4 million in 2014, compared to $32,000 in 2013. The decrease in 2014 was primarily a result of recovery of a prepaid item during 2014. An increase in inventories used cash of&#8201; $32.0 million in 2014, compared to a decrease in inventories providing cash of $33.5 million in 2013, primarily as a result of the consolidation of our acquisitions in 2014. An increase in account payables and accrued expenses (including derivative liabilities) provided cash of&#8201; $13.4 million in 2014, compared to $5.6 million in 2013. A decrease in receivables (including derivative assets) provided cash of&#8201; $3.6 million in 2014, compared to an increase in receivables using cash of&#8201; $38.7 million in 2013. A decrease in restricted cash provided cash of&#8201; $6.6 million in 2014, compared to $0.6 million in 2013. A decrease in short-term cash deposits provided cash of&#8201; $4.6 million in 2014, compared to an increase in short-term cash deposits using cash of&#8201; $4.3 million in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Cash Flows from Continuing Investing Activities
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Investing activities used cash of&#8201; $8.0 million in 2015, compared to $105.1 million in 2014, primarily in connection with our acquisitions in 2014. Purchases of property, plant and equipment, net of proceeds from dispositions, used cash of&#8201; $8.0 million in 2015, compared to $29.6 million in 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Investing activities used cash of&#8201; $105.1 million in 2014, compared to $0.9 million in 2013. Acquisitions of subsidiaries net of cash acquired used cash of&#8201; $74.1 million in 2014, primarily in connection with our acquisitions of two supply chain companies in 2014, compared to $6.6 million in 2013. Purchases of property, plant and equipment, net of proceeds from dispositions, primarily related to a power project in Alberta, Canada, used cash of&#8201; $29.6 million in 2014, compared to $1.6 million in 2013. An increase in loan receivables used cash of&#8201; $3.1 million in 2014, compared to $nil in 2013. Proceeds from sales of long-term investments provided cash of&#8201; $1.6 million in 2014, compared to $7.2 million in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Cash Flows from Continuing Financing Activities
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Net cash used by financing activities was $49.5 million in 2015, compared to net cash provided by financing activities of&#8201; $90.9 million in 2014. A net decrease in debt used cash of&#8201; $43.9 million in 2015, compared to a net increase in debt providing $127.7 million in 2014. In 2015, dividends paid to our shareholders used cash of&#8201; $4.4 million in connection with the fourth instalment of our 2014 dividend, which was paid in the first quarter of 2015, compared to $12.5 million in 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Net cash provided by financing activities was $90.9 million in 2014, compared to $89.9 million in 2013. A net increase in debt provided cash of&#8201; $127.7 million in 2014, compared to $82.5 million in 2013. In 2014, dividends paid to our shareholders used cash of&#8201; $12.5 million, compared to $15.4 million in 2013. The fourth installment of our dividend declared in 2014 was paid in January&nbsp;2015. A repayment to a customer
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	used cash of&#8201; $23.6 million in 2014, compared to providing cash of&#8201; $23.6 million in 2013. On December&nbsp;31, 2013, a customer paid $23.6 million to one of the Company&#8217;s subsidiaries. However, the underlying invoice was subject to factoring arrangements and the amount was subsequently repaid in January&nbsp;2014. As a result, $23.6 million was recognized as a repayment to a customer in 2014. No income or loss was recognized in connection with such transactions. Dividends paid to non-controlling interests used cash of $1.0 million in 2014, compared to $0.8 million in 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Cash Flows from Discontinued Operations
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Discontinued operating activities used cash of&#8201; $10.2 million in 2015, compared to providing cash of&#8201; $51.6 million and $45.3 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Discontinued investing activities used cash of&#8201; $2.0 million in 2015, compared to $13.7 million and $7.2 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Discontinued financing activities used cash of&#8201; $19.2 million in 2015, compared to $19.8 million and $41.1 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We maintain an adequate level of liquidity, with a portion of our assets held in cash and cash equivalents and securities. The liquid nature of these assets provides us with flexibility in managing and financing our business and the ability to realize upon investment or business opportunities as they arise. We also use this liquidity in client-related services by acting as a financial intermediary for third parties (e.g., by acquiring a position or assets and reselling such position or assets) and for our own proprietary trading and investing activities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, cash and cash equivalents decreased to $197.5 million from $344.9 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily as a result of the repayment of borrowings.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Trade receivables and other receivables were $151.2 million and $14.7 million, respectively, as December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $187.6 million and $26.4 million, respectively, as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease in
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	34
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	trade receivables was primarily as a result of collections, increased factoring and an increase in an allowance for credit losses, partially offset by the increase in receivables resulting from higher sales and the impact of the weaker Canadian dollar against the Euro.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Inventories decreased to $245.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $246.6 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, $13.7 million and $127.6 million of such inventories were initially financed by suppliers and short-term bank borrowings, respectively. $141.3 million of our inventories were contracted at fixed prices or hedged as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Assets held for sale, consisting of our discontinued operations, were $136.2 million, which consisted of certain hydrocarbon properties, iron ore interests and an amount due from our former subsidiaries, as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $152.1 million, which consisted of certain hydrocarbon properties and investment property, as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease in assets held for sale was a result of our decision to sell additional hydrocarbon properties, reduced by impairment losses recognized on the assets.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Deposits, prepaid and other assets were $21.4 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $9.0 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Tax receivables, consisting primarily of refundable value-added taxes, were $11.7 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $15.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We had short-term financial assets relating to derivatives of&#8201; $5.6 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $6.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. We had current liabilities relating to derivatives of&#8201; $3.6 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $2.0 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. Such derivatives relate to commodities and currencies.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Account payables and accrued expenses were $174.8 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $158.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was primarily due to the provision for payments under guarantees, partially offset by the reclassification of liabilities related to our assets held for sale and fluctuations in the timing of payments of certain invoices in the ordinary course of business.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had liabilities relating to assets held for sale of&#8201; $87.6 million, which included decommissioning obligations, bank debt and other liabilities associated with such assets, compared to $17.8 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014, which comprised decommissioning obligations only. The increase was as a result of a reclassification of assets held for sale as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our short-term bank borrowings decreased to $60.1 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $187.2 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. Total long-term debt decreased to $259.0 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $363.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily as a result of repayments and the re-classification of liabilities related to our assets held for sale. Our decommissioning obligations decreased to $nil as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from $150.3 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014, as a result of the re-classification of decommissioning obligations related to assets held for sale.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had deferred income tax liabilities of&#8201; $13.7 million, compared to $11.9 million as at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Short-Term Bank Loans and Facilities
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As part of our operations, we establish, utilize and maintain various kinds of credit lines and facilities with banks and insurers. Most of these facilities are short-term. These facilities are used in our day-to-day structured solutions and supply chain business. The amounts drawn under such facilities fluctuate with the kind and level of transactions being undertaken.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had credit facilities aggregating $900.8 million comprised of: (i)&nbsp;unsecured revolving credit facilities aggregating $429.6 million from banks. The banks generally charge an interest rate of inter-bank rates plus an interest margin; (ii) revolving credit facilities aggregating $116.2 million from banks for structured solutions, a special trade financing. The margin is negotiable when the facility is used; (iii) a non-recourse specially structured factoring arrangement with a bank for up to a credit limit of&#8201; $248.7 million for our supply chain activities. We may factor our receivable accounts upon invoicing at the inter-bank rate plus a margin; (iv) foreign exchange credit facilities of&#8201; $80.4 million with banks; and (v)&nbsp;secured revolving credit facilities aggregating $25.7 million. All of these facilities are either renewable on a yearly basis or usable until further notice. A substantial portion of our credit facilities are denominated in Euros and, accordingly, such amounts may fluctuate when reported in Canadian dollars.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	35
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In addition, we have margin lines with availability at multiple brokers, which enable us to hedge over $138.4 million (US$100.0 million) notional value of industrial products.
</DIV>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We expect our maturing debt to be satisfied primarily through the settlement of underlying supply chain transactions, trade financing transactions, including structured solutions transactions, cash on hand and cash flows from operations. Much of our maturing debt may either subsequently be made re-available to us by the applicable financial institution or we may replace such facilities with new facilities depending upon particular capital requirements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Please refer to Note 15 to our audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 for further information regarding interest rates, maturities and other terms and conditions for our bank debts.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Future Liquidity
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We expect that there will be acquisitions of businesses or commitments to projects in the future. To achieve the long-term goals of expanding our assets and earnings, including through acquisitions, capital resources will be required. Depending on the size of a transaction, the capital resources that will be required can be substantial. The necessary resources will be generated from cash flows from operations, cash on hand, borrowings against our assets, sales of proprietary investments or the issuance of securities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Foreign Currency
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Substantially all of our operations are conducted in international markets and our consolidated financial results are subject to foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Effective December&nbsp;31, 2015, our presentation currency is the Canadian dollar. We translate subsidiaries&#8217; assets and liabilities into Canadian dollars at the rate of exchange on the balance sheet date. Revenues and expenses are translated at exchange rates approximating those at the date of the transactions or, for practical reasons, the average exchange rates for the applicable periods, when they approximate the exchange rate as at the dates of the transactions. As a substantial amount of revenues is generated in Euros, the financial position for any given period, when reported in Canadian dollars, can be significantly affected by the exchange rates for these currencies prevailing during that period. In addition, we also have exposure to the Chinese yuan and the United States dollar.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we reported a net $79.5 million currency translation adjustment gain under other comprehensive income within equity. This compared to net gains of&#8201; $45.6 million and $16.9 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively. This currency translation adjustment did not affect our profit and loss statement. The increase in 2015 was primarily a result of the strengthening of the Euro and the United States dollar against the Canadian dollar and the increase in 2014 was primarily a result of the strengthening of the United States dollar against the Canadian dollar.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	36
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.19PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">

	(2)

</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.19PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	This table does not include non-financial instrument liabilities, guarantees and liabilities relating to assets held for sale.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Risk Management
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Risk is an inherent part of our business and operating activities. The extent to which we properly and effectively identify, assess, monitor and manage each of the various types of risk involved in our activities is critical to our financial soundness and profitability. We seek to identify, assess, monitor and manage the following principal risks involved in our business activities: market, credit, liquidity, operational, legal and compliance, new business, reputational and other. Risk management is a multi-faceted process that requires communication, judgment and knowledge of financial products and markets. Our management takes an active role in the risk management process and requires specific administrative and business functions to assist in the identification, assessment and control of various risks. Our risk management policies, procedures and methodologies are fluid in nature and are subject to ongoing review and modification.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Inflation
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We do not believe that inflation has had a material impact on our revenues or income over the past two fiscal years. However, increases in inflation could result in increases in our expenses, which may not be readily recoverable in the price of goods or services provided to our clients. To the extent that inflation results in rising interest rates and has other adverse effects on capital markets, it could adversely affect our financial position and profitability.
</DIV>

	(3)

	Includes losses of&#8201; $51.4 million related to a customer that filed for insolvency in February 2016 and $9.9 million on long-term off-take agreements entered into by a subsidiary acquired in 2014, which have since been terminated. Please see &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Item 5: Operating and Financial Review and Prospects&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Results of Operations

	&#8221; for further information.

<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(4)

	Includes non-cash impairments of&#8201; $52.9 million recognized on our hydrocarbon properties and the reversal of non-cash impairment losses of&#8201; $30.0 million and the recognition of a deferred tax liability of&#8201; $7.8 million in connection therewith.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;

<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(5)

<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;">
	Includes non-cash impairments of&#8201; $143.6 million, before a reduction of deferred tax assets of&#8201; $50.9 million, and $245.6 million, before an income tax recovery of&#8201; $54.3 million, respectively, recognized on our hydrocarbon properties and iron ore interests.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Notes:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(1)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;">
	We commenced consolidation of the operations of two acquired supply chain companies from March&nbsp;31 and April&nbsp;1, 2014, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(2)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;">
	Revenues and costs of sales and services for the periods have been reclassified to present certain transactions on a net basis. This had no impact on our net income from operations, net income, cash flow statements or financial position for such periods. Please see &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Item 5: Operating and Financial Review and Prospects &#8211; Prior Periods
</FONT>
	&#8221; for further information.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>

	(3)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:434.05PT;">
	Attributable to our shareholders.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(4)
<BR>

	Includes a non-cash impairment of interests in resource properties of&#8201; $33.2 million before an income tax recovery of&#8201; $8.4 million.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Application of Critical Accounting Policies
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires our management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Our management routinely makes judgments and estimates about the effects of matters that are inherently uncertain. As the number of variables and assumptions affecting the probable future resolution of the uncertainties increase, these judgments become even more subjective and complex. We have identified certain accounting policies that are the most important to the portrayal of our current financial condition and results of operations. Please refer to Note 1 to our audited consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 20-F for a discussion of the significant accounting policies.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	The following accounting policies are the most important to our ongoing financial condition and results of operations from continuing operations:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Allowance for Credit Losses
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	We apply credit risk assessment and valuation methods to our trade and other receivables. Credit losses arise primarily from receivables but may also relate to other credit instruments issued by or on our behalf, such as guarantees and letters of credit. An allowance for credit losses is increased by provisions which are charged to income and reduced by write-offs net of any recoveries.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Specific provisions are established on an individual receivable basis. A country risk provision may be made based on exposures in less developed countries and on our management&#8217;s overall assessment of the underlying economic conditions in those countries.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	38
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our allowance for credit losses is maintained at an amount considered adequate to absorb estimated credit-related losses. Such allowance reflects our management&#8217;s best estimate of the losses in our receivables and judgments about economic conditions. The assessment of allowance for credit losses is a complex process, which involve a significant degree of judgement and a high level of estimation uncertainty. The input factors include our legal rights and obligations under all the contracts and the expected future cash flows from the receivables and their collateral which include inventories, mortgages and other credit enhancement instruments. The major source of estimation uncertainty relates to the likelihood of the various scenarios under which different amounts are expected to be recovered through the security in place on the receivables. The expected future cash flows are projected under different scenarios and weighted by probability, which involves the exercise of significant judgment. Estimates and judgments could change in the near-term, and could result in a significant change to a recognized allowance.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In addition, we also provide credit losses for our credit exposures arising from guarantees we issued. The loss assessment process, as well as the exercise of judgment and estimation uncertainty, are similar to the preceding paragraph.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Classification of Assets Held for Sale
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We apply judgment to determine whether an asset (disposal group) is available for immediate sale in its present condition and that its sale is highly probable and therefore should be classified as held for sale at the balance sheet date. In order to assess whether it is highly probable that the sale can be completed within one year or the extension period in certain circumstances, our management reviews the business and economic factors, both macro and micro, which include the industry trends and capital markets. It is also open to all forms of sales, including exchanges of non-current assets for other non-current assets when the exchange will have commercial substance in accordance with IAS 16,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Property, Plant and Equipment
</FONT>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Non-Cash Impairment of Non-Financial Assets
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We assess at the end of each reporting period whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired. If any such indication exists, we estimate the recoverable amount of the asset. In assessing whether there is any indication that an asset may be impaired, we consider, as a minimum, the following indications:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	External sources of information
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:4.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(a)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:4.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	during the period, the asset&#8217;s market value has declined significantly more than would be expected as a result of the passage of time or normal use;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(b)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	significant changes with an adverse effect on the entity have taken place during the period, or will take place in the near future, in the technological, market, economic or legal environment in which the entity operates or in the market to which an asset is dedicated;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.41PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(c)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.41PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	market interest rates or other market rates of return on investments have increased during the period, and those increases are likely to affect the discount rate used in calculating an asset&#8217;s value in use and decrease the asset&#8217;s recoverable amount materially;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(d)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	the carrying amount of the net assets of the entity is more than its market capitalization;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Internal sources of information
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:4.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(e)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:4.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	evidence is available of obsolescence or physical damage of an asset;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.41PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(f)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.41PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	significant changes with an adverse effect on the entity have taken place during the period, or are expected to take place in the near future, in the extent to which, or manner in which, an asset is used or is expected to be used. These changes include the asset becoming idle, plans to discontinue or restructure the operation to which an asset belongs, plans to dispose of an asset before the previously expected date and reassessing the useful life of an asset as finite rather than indefinite; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	(g)
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:5.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	evidence is available from internal reporting that indicates that the economic performance of an asset is, or will be, worse than expected.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Income Taxes
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Management believes that it has adequately provided for income taxes based on all of the information that is currently available. The calculation of income taxes in many cases, however, requires significant judgment in interpreting tax rules and regulations, which are constantly changing.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	39
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
<A NAME="T1600851-20F_HTM_TI5NSIA">
	&#8203;
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our tax filings are also subject to audits, which could materially change the amount of current and deferred income tax assets and liabilities. Any change would be recorded as a charge or a credit to income tax expense. Any cash payment or receipt would be included in cash from operating activities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We currently have deferred income tax assets, which are comprised primarily of tax loss carry-forwards and deductible temporary differences, both of which will reduce taxable income in the future. The amounts recorded for deferred income tax assets are based upon various judgments, assumptions and estimates. We assess the realization of these deferred income tax assets on a periodic basis to determine to what extent it is probable that taxable profit will be available against which the deductible temporary differences and the carry-forward of unused tax credits and unused tax losses can be utilized. We determine whether it is probable that all or a portion of the deferred income tax assets will be realized, based on currently available information, including, but not limited to, the following:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	the history of the tax loss carry-forwards and their expiry dates;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	future reversals of temporary differences;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	our projected earnings; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:414.05PT;">
	tax planning opportunities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	On the reporting date, we also reassess unrecognized deferred income tax assets. We recognize a previously unrecognized deferred income tax asset to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profit will allow the deferred income tax asset to be recovered.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We provide for future liabilities in respect of uncertain tax positions where additional tax may become payable in future periods and such provisions are based on our management&#8217;s assessment of exposures. We do not recognize the full deferred income tax liability on taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries, joint ventures and associates where we are able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is probable that the temporary differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future. We may change our investment decision in the normal course of our business, thus resulting in additional tax liability.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	New Standards and Interpretations Adopted and Not Yet Adopted
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	IFRS 9,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Financial Instruments
</FONT>
	, referred to as &#8220;IFRS 9&#8221;, issued in July&nbsp;2014 is the IASB&#8217;s replacement of IAS 39,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement
</FONT>
	, referred to as &#8220;IAS 39&#8221;. IFRS 9 includes requirements for recognition and measurement, impairment, derecognition and general hedge accounting. The version of IFRS 9 issued in 2014 supersedes all previous versions and is mandatorily effective for periods beginning on or after January&nbsp;1, 2018 with early adoption permitted (subject to local endorsement requirements). Management has decided not to early apply IFRS 9 and is currently assessing the impacts of IFRS 9 on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	IFRS 15,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers
</FONT>
	, referred to as &#8220;IFRS 15&#8221;, specifies how and when an entity will recognize revenue as well as requiring such entities to provide users of financial statements with more informative, relevant disclosures. The standard provides a single, principles based five-step model to be applied to all contracts with customers. IFRS 15 was issued in May&nbsp;2014 and applies to annual periods beginning on or after January&nbsp;1, 2018. Management is currently assessing the impacts of IFRS 15 on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Amendments to IFRS 10,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Consolidated Financial Statements,
</FONT>
	and IAS 28,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures
</FONT>
	, were issued in September&nbsp;2014 and are effective for years beginning on or after January&nbsp;1, 2016, to be applied prospectively. The amendments require that upon loss of control of a subsidiary during its transfer to an associate or joint venture, full gain recognition on the transfer is appropriate only if the subsidiary meets the definition of a business in IFRS 3, to the extent of the company&#8217;s share and unless the principles of IFRS 3 conflict with the guidance under IFRS 11. Adoption of these amendments is not expected to have significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Amendments to IFRS 11,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Joint Arrangements
</FONT>
	, referred to as &#8220;IFRS 11&#8221;, were issued in May&nbsp;2014 and are effective for years beginning on or after January&nbsp;1, 2016, to be applied prospectively. The amendments clarify that an acquisition of an interest in a joint operation that is a business should be accounted for by a company and disclosed as a business combination in accordance with IFRS 3,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Business Combinations
</FONT>
	, referred to as &#8220;IFRS 3&#8221;, to the extent of the company&#8217;s share and unless the principles of IFRS conflict with the guidance under IFRS 11. Adoption of these amendments is not expected to have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	40
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We do not have any off-balance sheet arrangements that have or are reasonably likely to have a current or future effect on our financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources that are material to investors.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We have outstanding issued guarantees held by our external trading and financial partners in connection with our finance and supply chain activities. As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had issued guarantees of up to a maximum of&#8201; $14.1 million, being the total potential principal amount that may be guaranteed thereunder, of which $0.4 million were outstanding and have not been recorded as liabilities in our consolidated statement of financial position. There has been no claim against the guarantees.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
