</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Hydrocarbon properties
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In September&nbsp;2015, the Group&#8217;s realized pricing of natural gas, natural gas liquids and oil had declined since December&nbsp;31, 2014. As such, as at September&nbsp;30, 2015, the Group performed an impairment assessment on its hydrocarbon properties utilizing post-tax discount rates between 10% and 13% and recognized a non-cash impairment loss of&#8201; $143,609. As a result of the impairment charge, a previously recorded deferred tax asset of&#8201; $50,918 had to be written off. This non-cash impairment comprised $46,715 allocated to interests in resource properties, $16,108 to probable reserves, $33,114 to property, plant and equipment and $47,672 to the properties previously included in assets held for sale. In the fourth quarter of 2015, the Group recognized an additional impairment loss of&#8201; $52,940.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	On December&nbsp;30, 2015, the Group sold a 95% economic interest in certain hydrocarbon assets and the related liabilities to a third party for nominal and contingent consideration (see Note 23). Based on the terms of the transaction, the Group continued to be registered holder of the entities holding these assets and liabilities but lost power to direct the business activities of these subsidiaries. As such, effective December&nbsp;30, 2015 the Group ceased consolidating these entities (the former subsidiaries). No gain or loss was recognized upon the disposition. However, a deferred tax expense of&#8201; $11,987 was recognized resulting from the write-off of previously recognized deferred tax assets. Furthermore, as a result of the deconsolidation of the former subsidiaries, a net receivable of&#8201; $11,600 due from the former subsidiaries was recognized as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 as the amount was no longer eliminated within the Group and was included in assets held for sale. The remaining economic interest has been recognized at a nominal value as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In December&nbsp;2014, the Group&#8217;s realized pricing of natural gas, natural gas liquids and oil declined 20%, 32% and 35%, respectively. As such, as at December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Group performed an annual impairment assessment on its hydrocarbon properties utilizing post-tax discount rates between 8.5% and 9.0% and recognized an impairment loss of&#8201; $33,200 before a deferred income tax recovery of&#8201; $8,372. This impairment is comprised of&#8201; $18,780 allocated to interests in resource properties, $7,191 to probable reserves, $3,707 to unproved lands and $3,522 to assets held for sale.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Group performed an annual impairment assessment on its hydrocarbon properties based on a pre-tax discount rate of 10% and recognized an impairment loss of&#8201; $6,463 before an income tax recovery of&#8201; $1,660.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Interests in iron ore mines
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In the first quarter of 2015, the operator of the iron ore mine in Canada in which the Group has a royalty interest commenced proceedings under the Companies&#8217; Creditors Arrangement Act (Canada) (the &#8220;CCAA&#8221;) with respect to its Canadian operations and publicly disclosed that its assets comprising the mine will be included in any sales process.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In the third quarter of 2015, the long-term price curve of iron ore continued to deteriorate. Management of the Group reviewed the underlying legal documents and performed a sensitivity analysis on the expected future cash flows from its royalty interest. Consideration was given to reasonably possible scenarios,
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	100
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage111"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assets Classified as Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	including the Company exercising its step-in rights and re-taking the mine. The primary factors which impact the recoverable amount, among others, are the number of years of production, iron ore pricing and/&#8203;or production costs. Each possible scenario was assigned a probability. Based on the cash flows projections, management determined that a non-cash impairment loss of&#8201; $218,203 was required, before a deferred income tax recovery of&#8201; $54,305, as at September&nbsp;30, 2015, to write down the carrying amount of its interest to a nominal amount. In the fourth quarter of 2015, the Group reversed the previously recognized impairment loss by $30,000 and recognized a related deferred tax liability of&#8201; $7,800. The reversal of the previously recognized impairment loss reflected the improvements in the expected future cash flows under possible scenarios, using a pre-tax discount rate of 9% and taking into consideration events that occurred subsequent to the third quarter of 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group also reviewed the cash flow projections for the iron ore development project located in the United States. Given the reduced viability of this project, high capital cost to complete requisite studies and management&#8217;s business focus on trade finance banking activities, management determined that an impairment loss of&#8201; $27,397 was required, before a deferred income tax recovery of&#8201; $nil, as at September&nbsp;30, 2015, to write down the carrying amount of its interest to a nominal amount.
</DIV>

	There were no impairment charges on the Group&#8217;s interests in iron ore mines during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013.
</DIV>

<TR STYLE="HEIGHT:4PT;LINE-HEIGHT:4PT;">
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;" COLSPAN="9">
	&#8203;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:10.6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, there was a net cumulative translation adjustment loss of&#8201; $20,772 arising from the translation of the financial position of the disposal groups into the Canadian dollar reporting currency, which has been included in accumulated other comprehensive income under equity. The cumulative translation adjustment loss is subject to further changes resulting from the fluctuation of the underlying functional currencies of the disposal groups against the Canadian dollar and will be reclassified to profit or loss upon the disposal of the subsidiaries and/or operations.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	If the disposal groups had been re-presented in the statement of financial position as of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the following non-current assets and associated decommissioning obligations would have been reclassified and included in assets held for sale and liabilities relating to assets held for sale:
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:20PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Business Segment Information
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group is primarily in the finance and supply chain business, which includes marketing activities, captive supply assets, structured solutions, financial services and proprietary investing activities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In reporting to management, the Group&#8217;s operating results are categorized into the following operating segments: finance and supply chain and all other segments.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Previously, the Group presented its finance and supply chain business in two reportable segments, global supply chain and trade finance and services. However, as the Group has advanced its long-term strategy, the divide between these two segments has become less clear while the revenue and cost synergies have become more apparent. Therefore, as a result of the integrated nature of these operations, the Group has combined these two former segments into the finance and supply chain segment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Basis of Presentation
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In reporting segments, certain of the Group&#8217;s business lines have been aggregated where they have similar economic characteristics and are similar in each of the following areas: (i) the nature of the products and services; (ii) the methods of distribution, and (iii) the types or classes of customers/clients for the products and services.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group provides supply chain services, logistics and other trade and structured finance services to producers and consumers of the Group&#8217;s products. The trade finance and services business also provides supply chain structured solutions. These activities provide cost effective and efficient transportation, as well
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	102
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage113"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Business Segment Information&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	as payment terms accommodating working capital requirements of the Group&#8217;s customers and partners. The Group&#8217;s operations often utilize strategies and structures to facilitate the working capital needs of the Group&#8217;s clients. The Group supplies various products, including metals, ceramics, minerals, various steel products and ferro-alloys and wood products. The Group also seeks investments in many industries, emphasizing those business opportunities where the perceived intrinsic value is not properly recognized. The Group uses its financial and management expertise to add or unlock value within a relatively short time period.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The all other segment includes the Group&#8217;s corporate and operating segments whose quantitative amounts do not exceed 10% of any of the Group&#8217;s (a) reported revenue, (b) net income or (c) total assets. The Group&#8217;s other operating segments primarily include business activities in medical equipment, instruments, supplies and services.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The accounting policies of the operating segments are the same as those described in the summary of significant accounting policies. The chief operating decision maker evaluates performance on the basis of income or loss from operations before income taxes and does not consider acquisition accounting adjustments in assessing the performance of the Group&#8217;s reporting segments. The segment information presented below is prepared according to the following methodologies: (a) revenues and expenses directly associated with each segment are included in determining pre-tax earnings; (b) intersegment sales and transfers are accounted for as if the sales or transfers were to third parties at current market prices; (c)&nbsp;certain selling, general and administrative expenses paid by corporate, particularly incentive compensation and share-based compensation, are not allocated to reporting segments; (d) all intercompany investments, receivables and payables are eliminated in the determination of each segment&#8217;s assets and liabilities; and (e) deferred income tax assets and liabilities are not allocated.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The segment information for prior years presented has been restated to reflect the combination of the two former reportable segments of global supply chain and trade finance and services into the finance and supply chain segment. All data and discussions on revenues, expenses, income and loss in this Note 5 relate to the Group&#8217;s continuing operations only and do not include discontinued operations.
</DIV>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_50"></A>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.98PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Geographic Information
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Due to the highly integrated nature of international products and services, finance and supply chain activities and markets, and a significant portion of the Group&#8217;s activities requiring cross-border coordination in order to serve the Group&#8217;s customers and clients, the methodology for allocating the Group&#8217;s profitability to geographic regions is dependent on estimates and management judgment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Geographic results are generally determined as follows:
</DIV>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:414.55PT;HEIGHT:50.5PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:8PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">
<TR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;VERTICAL-ALIGN:BOTTOM;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT 0PT 2.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:144.55PT;">

	Segment
</FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT 0PT 2.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:258PT;">

	&#8203;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Trade Receivables&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, trade receivables of&#8201; $13,918 (2014: $76,301) were past due but not impaired. The aging analyses of these trade receivables as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 are as follows:
</DIV>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:414.55PT;HEIGHT:99PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:8PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">
<TR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;VERTICAL-ALIGN:BOTTOM;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">

<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
<FONT STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;PADDING-BOTTOM:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:1PT;">
	Past-due
</FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;

<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;

<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT 0PT 2.5PT 0PT;" COLSPAN="4">
<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
<FONT STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;PADDING-BOTTOM:1PT;PADDING-LEFT:15PT;PADDING-RIGHT:15PT;">
	2015
</FONT>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:11.39PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, trade receivables of&#8201; $37,454 (2014: $37,969) were impaired and an allowance for credit losses of&#8201; $21,210 (2014: $9,255) has been provided. Not all past-due account balances are uncollectible as most of the accounts are covered by credit insurance or other collection procedures. Credit risk from trade account receivables is mitigated since they are credit insured, covered by letters of credit, bank guarantees and/or other credit enhancements (see Note 26). The aging analyses of impaired trade receivables as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 are as follows:

	The recoverable amount of impaired receivables is covered by credit insurance, bank guarantees and/or other credit enhancements and, therefore, management of the Group believes this entire net amount to be collectible in the ordinary course of business.

	A substantial amount of the impaired trade receivables that were past-due for over one year as at December&nbsp;31, 2014 were related to one customer and settled during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:11.89PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2015, a customer of the Group filed for insolvency. This is an adjusting subsequent event under IAS 10 and, as a result, the Group had to determine an allowance for credit losses against the Group&#8217;s receivables due from this customer and its affiliates. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Group
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">

	106

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Trade Receivables&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	had gross trade receivables of&#8201; $103,300 due from this customer and its affiliates as well as other contracts with such customer. The Group conducted an extensive assessment of impairment losses on these trade receivables. This assessment involved a number of judgments and a high level of estimation uncertainty. The factors considered in these estimates include the Group&#8217;s legal rights and obligations under all related contracts and collateral, which include inventories, mortgages, insurance of collateral and other credit enhancement instruments. The Group recognized an allowance for credit losses of&#8201; $10,705 in connection with this customer and its affiliates as at December&nbsp;31, 2015. After the recognition of such impairment losses, the Group had trade receivables of&#8201; $92,595 due from this customer and its affiliates as at December&nbsp;31, 2015. See Note 23 for further information.
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12.99PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, inventories with a carrying amount of&#8201; $54,635 were pledged as security for liabilities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, inventories aggregating $141,344 (2014: $127,407) had been contracted to be sold at fixed prices or hedged, of which $13,697 (2014: $17,079) and $127,647 (2014: $110,328), respectively, were initially financed by suppliers and short-term bank borrowings.
</DIV>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_59"></A>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:41PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 10.
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:413.05PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Investment Property
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Investment property was classified as non-current assets prior to September&nbsp;30, 2013. In September&nbsp;2013, management committed to a plan to sell its investment property. As a result, the Group&#8217;s investment property was classified as held for sale and included in current assets as at December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013. In September&nbsp;2015, management ceased to classify its investment property as held for sale and, thus, included it in non-current assets as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16.8PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, land and buildings with net carrying amount of&#8201; $2,352 were used as security against bank debt (see Note 15).
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	During 2015, 2014 and 2013, $3,948, $23,415 and $400, respectively, of expenditures were recognized in the carrying amount of items of property, plant and equipment in the course of their construction.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; MARGIN-TOP:13PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:41PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 12.
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:13PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:413.05PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Accrued Pension Assets (Obligations)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group currently has post-retirement defined benefit plans for its employees in Austria, Norway, Germany and Mexico. In addition there is a small jubilee pay plan for an Austrian entity, which is based on collective agreements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The majority of the Group&#8217;s post-retirement defined benefit pension plans are funded. These are pension arrangements for managers in Germany and Austria and a closed pension plan for former employees in Norway.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	109
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_65"></A>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:41PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 12.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:413.05PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Accrued Pension Assets (Obligations)&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The major defined benefit pension plan in Norway is closed to new employees and provides retirement and death benefits to former employees and is administered by management. The plan provides no lump sum option and the indexation of benefits is limited to surplus spending of the insurance contract.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The defined benefit pension plans in Germany and Austria are based on single pension promises to four former managers and one active manager and are partly funded. These pension plans provide retirement, disability and death benefits. The related plan assets are held separately by an independent insurance company.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In Austria and Mexico termination indemnity plans are provided to employees. These plans are required to be provided by companies based on local labor laws. They are unfunded and closed to new employees in Austria. These termination indemnity plans provide lump sum benefits in the case of retirement, disability and death.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group had a defined benefit pension plan for its employees in Canada which was classified as assets held for sale which was subsequently disposed of during 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">

<A NAME="eolPage122"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:41PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 12.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:413.05PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Accrued Pension Assets (Obligations)&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The defined benefit obligation sensitivity figures were calculated using the same methods and assumptions as the December&nbsp;31, 2015 defined benefit obligation figures, with the only assumption change being the 1% change in discount rate or salary scale, respectively, as indicated. There was no change from the previous period in the methods and assumptions used in preparing the sensitivity analyses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As is the case with the actuarial valuations, formal materiality guidelines were not employed in the derivation of the sensitivity analyses. The defined benefits pension obligations were valued using assumptions adopted for each relevant contingency and membership data that were reviewed for consistency with previous data as well as overall reasonableness. To the extent that the assumptions and methods adopted for the valuations were appropriate for the purpose of the valuations; nothing was omitted as being immaterial. Nevertheless, emerging experience differing from the assumptions will result in gains or losses that will be revealed in future valuations and could affect the validity of the sensitivity analyses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Plan assets
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Plan assets are generally held and administered by independent financial services companies. The assets do not include the Group&#8217;s own financial instruments or any property occupied by, or other assets used by, the Group.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Expected contributions and benefit payments
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The expected contributions in 2016 from the employers and employees are $422 and $nil, respectively. The employer contributions represent the Group&#8217;s minimum required contribution under pension legislation.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Group&#8217;s expected benefit payments are as follows:

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The utilization of the deferred tax assets is dependent on future taxable profits in excess of the profits arising from the reversal of existing taxable temporary differences and the Group companies have suffered losses in either the current or preceding period(s) in the tax jurisdictions to which the deferred tax assets relate.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2015, MFC Bancorp had an aggregate amount of&#8201; $62,478 of temporary differences associated with its investments in subsidiaries and branches, for which deferred income tax liabilities have not been recognized because the Group is in a position to control the timing of the reversal of such temporary differences and it is probable that such differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In November&nbsp;2012 and February&nbsp;2016, the Company received from the Canada Revenue Agency (&#8220;CRA&#8221;) tax notices of reassessment relating to taxation years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 to April&nbsp;19, 2013. The reassessments deny a deduction in computing income, attribute income earned by predecessors to the Company and deny the application of losses and deductions by predecessors in computing their taxable income, and deny the application of credits in the computation of income taxes payable. The Company has filed notices of objection to the November&nbsp;2012 notices of reassessment. The period for filing notices of objection to the February&nbsp;2016 notices of reassessment has not yet expired. Notices of objection will be filed to the February&nbsp;2016 notices of reassessment in due course. The Company, among other things, reviewed the reassessments, the material facts related thereto and the subject transactions and consulted its advisors. Based on such review, management determined that the probability of the CRA&#8217;s reassessments being successful in court was remote. Accordingly, the Company has not recorded a liability in these consolidated financial statements in connection with the reassessments. There can be no assurance that the Company will be successful in defending its positions. If the CRA is successful in respect of either reassessment, then the Company will be required to pay a material amount of income tax plus applicable interest. There continues to be tax litigation in progress involving the CRA and other companies which may have a bearing on the Company&#8217;s own income tax position with the CRA. The Company will continue to assess its position as such litigation progresses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group companies&#8217; income tax filings are also subject to audit by taxation authorities in numerous jurisdictions. There are audits in progress and items under review, some of which may increase the Group&#8217;s income tax liability. In the event that management&#8217;s estimate of the future resolution of these matters changes, the Group will recognize the effects of the changes in its consolidated financial statements in the appropriate period relative to when such changes occur.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	113
</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Note 14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short-term Bank Borrowings
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.61PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Short-term bank borrowings are repayable within a year from the borrowing date. They are used to finance the Group&#8217;s day-to-day finance and supply chain business.
</DIV>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:414.55PT;HEIGHT:23.5PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:8PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">

	&#8203;

</TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:7.62PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Group had credit facilities aggregating $900,763 as follows: (i) the Group had unsecured revolving credit facilities aggregating $429,635 from banks. The banks generally charge an interest rate at inter-bank rate plus an interest margin; (ii) the Group also had revolving credit facilities aggregating $116,232 from banks for structured solutions, a special trade financing. The margin is negotiable when the facility is used; (iii) the Group had a specially structured non-recourse factoring arrangement with a bank up to a credit limit of&#8201; $248,730 for the Group&#8217;s finance and supply chain activities. The Group factors certain of its trade receivable accounts upon invoicing, at inter-bank rate plus a margin; (iv) the Group had foreign exchange credit facilities of&#8201; $80,446 with banks; and (v) the Group had secured revolving credit facilities aggregating $25,720. All these facilities are renewable on a yearly basis or usable until further notice.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.61PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	In addition, the Group has margin lines with availability at multiple brokers, which enable the Group to hedge over $138,400 notional value of industrial products.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Note 15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Debt
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.61PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:11.99PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Trade payables arise from the Group&#8217;s day-to-day trading activities. The Group&#8217;s expenses for services and other operational expenses are included in account and other payables. Generally, these payables and accrual accounts do not bear interest and have a maturity of less than one year.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 17.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shareholders&#8217; Equity
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Capital Stock
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The authorized share capital of MFC Bancorp consists of an unlimited number of common shares and class A common shares both without par value and without special rights or restrictions and an unlimited number of Class A Preference shares without par value and with special rights and restrictions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Holders of common shares may receive dividends when, as and if declared by the Board of Directors, subject to the preferential dividend rights of any other classes or series of preferred shares issued and outstanding. In no event may a dividend be declared or paid on the common shares if payment of the dividend would cause the realizable value of the assets of the Company to be less than the aggregate of its liabilities. Holders of common shares are entitled to one vote per share at any meeting of shareholders of common shares, and in general and subject to applicable law, all matters will be determined by a majority of votes cast other than fundamental changes with respect to the Company. The holders of common shares are entitled, in the event of a distribution of assets of the Company on the liquidation, dissolution or winding-up of the Company (a &#8220;Liquidation Distribution&#8221;), to receive, before any Liquidation Distribution is made to the holders of the class A common shares or any other shares of the Company ranking junior to the common shares, but after any prior rights of any preferred shares, the stated capital with respect to each common share held by them, together with all declared and unpaid dividends (if any and if preferential) thereon, up to the date of such Liquidation Distribution, and thereafter the common shares shall rank pari passu with all other classes of common shares in connection with the Liquidation Distribution.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The rights and restrictions attaching to the class A common shares are the same as those attaching to the common shares, except that in the event of a Liquidation Distribution, the holders of the class A common shares are entitled to receive such Liquidation Distribution only after any prior rights of the preferred shares and common shares or any other share ranking prior in right to the class A common shares.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Class A Preference shares may include one or more series and the Board of Directors may alter the special rights of and restrictions to such series. Except as may be set out in the rights and restrictions, the holders of the Class A Preference shares are not entitled to vote at or attend shareholder meetings. Holders of Class A Preference shares are entitled to receive repayment of capital on the liquidation or dissolution of MFC Bancorp before distribution is made to holders of common shares.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	All of the Company&#8217;s issued capital stock are fully paid.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	116
</DIV>
</DIV>

</EFX_STOCKHOLDERS_EQUITY>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	All of the Company&#8217;s treasury stock is held by wholly-owned subsidiaries. The dividends paid and payable on the treasury stock by the Company are eliminated on consolidation.
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12.98PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group&#8217;s revenues include the revenues of the Elsner group and FESIL group from April&nbsp;1, 2014 in the finance and supply chain segment.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:20PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share-Based Compensation
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.21PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	MFC Bancorp has a 2014 Equity Incentive Plan which replaced the 1997 Stock Option Plan and 2008 Equity Incentive Plan.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	1997 Stock Option Plan (Amended)
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.21PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Subject to the terms of the 1997 Stock Option Plan (Amended) (&#8220;1997 Plan&#8221;), the Company granted options to certain employees and directors to acquire common shares of the Company.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	2008 Equity Incentive Plan
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.21PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Subject to the terms of the 2008 Equity Incentive Plan (&#8220;2008 Plan&#8221;), a committee, as appointed by the Company&#8217;s Board of Directors, granted nonqualified stock options, incentive stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock awards, stock unit awards, stock awards, performance stock awards and tax bonus awards under the plan.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	2014 Equity Incentive Plan
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5.21PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Pursuant to the terms of the 2014 Equity Incentive Plan (&#8220;2014 Plan&#8221;), the Company&#8217;s Board of Directors, the compensation committee or such other committee as appointed by the Board of Directors to
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	118
</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share-Based Compensation&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	administer the 2014 Plan, may grant stock options, restricted stock rights, restricted stock, performance share awards, performance share units and stock appreciation rights under the 2014 Plan, establish the terms and conditions for those awards, construe and interpret the 2014 Plan and establish the rules for the 2014 Plan&#8217;s administration. Such awards may be granted to employees, non-employee directors, officers or consultants of the Group or any affiliate or any person to whom an offer of employment with the Group or any affiliate is extended. Such committee has the authority to determine which employees, non-employee directors, officers, consultants and prospective employees should receive such awards. The 2014 Plan replaced the 1997 Plan and the 2008 Plan; provided, however, that the 1997 and 2008 Plans will continue to govern prior awards granted under such plans until all awards granted under such plans prior to November&nbsp;14, 2014 have been exercised, forfeited, cancelled, expired or otherwise terminated in accordance with the terms thereof.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The maximum number of the Company&#8217;s common shares that may be issuable pursuant to all awards granted under the 2014 Plan is 2,877,018 common shares, being 2,000,000 plus 267,344 and 609,674 of common shares available for awards under the 1997 and 2008 Plan, respectively, as of the effective date of the 2014 Plan. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the maximum number of shares that may be issued as incentive stock options under the 2014 Plan is 2,000,000. Forfeited, cancelled, returned and lapsed awards are not counted against the 2,000,000 common shares. Any awards granted under the 2014 Plan, or portions thereof, that are settled in cash and not by issuance of the Company&#8217;s common shares are not counted against the foregoing limits.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12.39PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	On April&nbsp;2, 2014, the Company granted to two employees options to purchase 200,000 MFC Bancorp common shares in aggregate at an exercise price of US$8.01 per share. The options vested immediately and expire on April&nbsp;2, 2019.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:3PT 0.5PT 1PT 0PT; WIDTH:78.32PT;TEXT-ALIGN:RIGHT;">
<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP; TEXT-ALIGN:RIGHT;">
	$2.115 (US$1.917)&#8203;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT; WIDTH:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16.59PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The expected volatility was determined based on the historical price movement over the expected option life, with adjustments for underlying businesses. The stock option holders are not entitled to dividends or dividend equivalents until the options are exercised.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The aggregate fair value of options granted was $423 which was recognized as share-based compensation expense in the Group&#8217;s consolidated statement of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The share-based compensation expense is not tax deductible under the Canadian income tax act and, therefore, the Group did not recognize any tax benefit from granting stock options.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	MFC Bancorp&#8217;s statutory tax rate was 26.0%, 26.0% and 25.75% in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. The increase in the tax rate in 2014 was due to the increase in the British Columbia provincial corporation tax rate effective from April&nbsp;2013.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	120
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.48PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In addition, the aggregate current and deferred income tax relating to items that are charged directly to equity was an expense of&#8201; $109 and a recovery of&#8201; $445 and $82, respectively, in 2015, 2014 and 2013, relating to the changes in fair values of available-for-sale securities and the remeasurements of defined benefit pension plans.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 21.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings Per Share
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 21.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings Per Share&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, there were 2,232,500 and 2,325,000 stock options, respectively, outstanding that could potentially dilute basic earnings per share in the future, but were not included in the calculation of diluted earnings per share because they were antidilutive for 2015 and 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Pursuant to a share purchase agreement (as amended), 50,000 common shares of MFC Bancorp would be issued to a put holder for each year from 2014 to 2024 if Possehl achieves an annual net income milestone as computed under IFRS for the year (see Note 25). The net income milestone for 2015 had been achieved, subject to the audit. These 50,000 contingently issuable shares will dilute basic earnings per share in the future, but were not included in the calculation of diluted earnings per share in 2015 because they were antidilutive.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 22.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dividends paid
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Company did not declare dividends in 2015. The last and final 2014 quarterly dividends of&#8201; $4,388 (or US$0.06 per common share) were paid on January&nbsp;5, 2015 to shareholders of record on December&nbsp;29, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 23.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Leases as lessors
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group leases out land and buildings and equipment under non-cancellable operating lease agreements. The leases have varying terms, subject to the customary practices in the particular regions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:11.99PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The leases have varying terms, subject to the customary practices in the local regions. The Group recognized rental and lease income of&#8201; $5,345, $2,821 (including sublease of&#8201; $7) and $2,435 (including sublease of&#8201; $14) for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Leases as lessees
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Future minimum commitments under long-term non-cancellable operating leases are as follows:

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_84"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:414.55PT;HEIGHT:114PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:8PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">
<TR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;VERTICAL-ALIGN:BOTTOM;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT 0PT 2.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:364.01PT;">
<DIV STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
<FONT STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;PADDING-BOTTOM:1PT;PADDING-RIGHT:1PT;">
	Years ending December&nbsp;31:
</FONT>
</DIV>

<A NAME="eolPage133"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 23.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The leases, which principally comprise office space, have varying terms, subject to the customary practices in the local regions. Minimum lease payments recognized as expenses were $3,569 (including sublease of $875), $3,953 (including sublease of&#8201; $218 and contingent rents of&#8201; $87) and $2,489 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014, and 2013 respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Litigation
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group is subject to litigation and tax audits in the normal course of business, the ultimate results of which cannot be ascertained at this time. The Group records costs as they are incurred or become determinable.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Guarantees
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Guarantees are accounted for as contingent liabilities unless it becomes probable that the Group will be required to make a payment under the guarantee.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group coordinated prepayment loans made by third-party banks to one of its customers, which financed off-take contracts to the Group. The Group has guaranteed the bank loans which were previously classified and disclosed as contingent liabilities. Subsequent to December 31, 2015, the customer filed for insolvency. Management of the Group expects that the banks will exercise their contractual rights under the guarantees to demand the payments from the Group and, as a result, the Group recorded a provision of $40,677 for the expected payments under the guarantees and a credit loss of&#8201; $40,677 thereon as at December 31, 2015. The Group holds various collateral, including guarantees, mortgages and other mitigation securities to recover a significant portion of these losses. The Group is exercising its rights as it undertakes various options to maximize recoveries. See sub-heading &#8220;Contingent Gain&#8221; in this Note 23.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Excluding the guarantee transaction discussed in the preceding paragraph, as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Group had issued guarantees up to a maximum of&#8201; $14,137 to its trade and financing partners in the normal course of its finance and supply chain activities, being the total potential principal amount that may be guaranteed, of which $390 were outstanding and have not been recorded as liabilities in the consolidated statement of financial position.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Purchase Obligations
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2015 the Group had open purchase contracts aggregating $71,865 due in 2016 relating to its finance and supply chain activities. None of these have been recognized in the consolidated statement of financial position as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Contingent Gain
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Subsequent to December 31, 2015, a customer filed for insolvency. As a result, the Group made a provision of&#8201; $40,677 as credit loss for the expected payments under the guarantees during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. However, the Group holds various collateral, including guarantees, mortgages and other mitigation securities to recover a significant portion of these losses. The Group is exercising its rights as it undertakes various options to maximize recoveries. The Group has not recorded any probable expected recoveries related to such credit losses in these consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In December&nbsp;2015, the Group sold a 95% economic interest in certain hydrocarbon assets and the related liabilities to a third party for nominal and contingent consideration. In the event that the purchaser sells, transfers or disposes of all or a portion of the participating interest in one or more transactions on or before the fifth anniversary date of the participating interest purchase and sale agreement and receives, collects or is otherwise entitled to aggregate proceeds equal to or greater than $5,000, it shall pay an amount equal to 25% thereof to the Group. As a result of the significant uncertainties as to the probability of receipt of any future consideration, management determined that the expected value of such future cash flow was $nil as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	123
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage134"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600851-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 23.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Effective April&nbsp;2014, the Group sold its interests in two aluminum processing mills to a third party. Pursuant to the share purchase agreement, the sale price includes a certain percentage of the disposed entity&#8217;s (1) free cash flow from operations for the fiscal years 2014 through and inclusive of 2016 and (2)&nbsp;proceeds from the dispositions of assets during a period of five years commencing on the day of the share purchase agreement. As a result of the significant uncertainties as to the probability of receipt of any future consideration, management determined that the expected value of such future cash flow was $nil as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In February&nbsp;2013, the Group sold its interests in extracting facilities. Pursuant to the share purchase agreement, the sale price includes a certain percentage of the sold entity&#8217;s future free cash flows from operations and investment for a period of seven years. As a result of the significant uncertainties as to the probability of receipt of any future consideration, management determined that the expected value of such future cash flow was $nil as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 24.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows &#8211; Supplemental Disclosure
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Interest paid and received, dividends received and income taxes paid are classified as operating activities. Dividends paid are classified as financing activities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group establishes, utilizes and maintains various kinds of credit lines and facilities with banks and insurers. Most of these facilities are short term. These facilities are used in our day-to-day supply chain business and structured solutions activities. The amounts drawn under such facilities fluctuate with the kind and level of transactions being undertaken. As a result, management considers short-term bank borrowings to be a part of its operating activities and that it is most appropriate to include the changes in short-term bank borrowings within operating activities on the consolidated statements of cash flows.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	There are no circumstances in which cash and cash equivalents held by an entity are not available for use by the Group.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	On December&nbsp;31, 2013, a customer paid $23,576 to one of the Group&#8217;s subsidiaries. However, the underlying invoice was subject to a factoring arrangement with a bank pursuant to which such bank had previously purchased the related receivable and the customer was to submit such payment to the bank directly. The amount, which had been incorrectly paid to the Group&#8217;s subsidiary by the customer instead of as directed to the bank, was subsequently repaid in January&nbsp;2014. As a result, $23,576 was recognized as repayment to a customer. No income or loss was recognized in connection with such transactions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The Group had the following non-cash transactions:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Non-cash transactions in 2015: (1) recognition of a non-cash gain of&#8201; $1,194 on the reversal of a decommissioning obligation (which was included in costs of sales and services), (2) issuance of 50,000 common shares of MFC Bancorp to a director pursuant to a share purchase agreement executed in 2014 (see Note 25), (3) the Group sold a 95% participating interest in certain hydrocarbon assets and liabilities, resulting in a post-tax loss of&#8201; $11,987 on disposition which was included in the results of discontinued operations and a net receivable of&#8201; $11,600 due from the former subsidiaries (see Notes 4 and 23) and (4) the Group recognized provisions of&#8201; $40,677 for expected payments under the guarantee (see Note 23).
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Non-cash transactions in 2014: (1) conversion of puttable instrument financial liabilities into the share capital of the Company (see Note 25) and (2) the Group sold its interest in a group of German entities and recognized a non-cash accounting gain of&#8201; $4,535 on disposition (see Note 28).
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Non-cash transactions in 2013: (1) conversion of puttable instrument financial liabilities into the share capital of non-wholly-owned subsidiaries; (2) the Group sold its interest in a group (which held the resource properties in India) and recognized a non-cash accounting gain of&#8201; $427 on disposition and (3) the Group acquired the non-controlling interests in a group for no consideration, resulting in $1,561 credited to the retained earnings account.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	124
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 25.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In the normal course of operations, the Group enters into transactions with related parties which include affiliates in which the Group has a significant equity interest (10% or more) or has the ability to influence their operating and financing policies through significant shareholding, representation on the board of directors, corporate charter and/or bylaws. The related parties also include MFC Bancorp&#8217;s directors, President, Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer and their close family members, as well as any person and entity which have significant influence over MFC Bancorp. In addition to transactions disclosed elsewhere in these consolidated financial statements, the Group had the following transactions with its related parties.
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_85"></A>

<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:10.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	*
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:10.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Related to transactions with two processing facilities, which are owned by a former subsidiary of the Company. One of the Company&#8217;s employees and one of its directors held unpaid positions on the board of directors of the parent company of the owner of these facilities until July&nbsp;2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	**
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	The director (who is also the former President of the Company) provided office space and services to the Company at cost.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	***
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:10PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:434.05PT;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
	Pursuant to a consulting agreement, the former President of the Company was entitled to a termination payment of US$1,770 upon the termination of the consulting agreement.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">
	Puttable instrument financial liabilities
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In connection with the acquisitions of Mexico City-based Possehl Mexico S.A. de C.V. (&#8220;Possehl&#8221;) in November&nbsp;2012, the Group entered into call and put agreements with the non-controlling interests, which allowed or required the Group to acquire up to 100% in the entity. As a result of the put options (i.e. puttable instrument), the non-controlling interests were classified as financial liabilities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In April&nbsp;2014, the Group entered into a share purchase agreement with the holder of the puttable instrument (the &#8220;Put Holder&#8221;) whereby the Group acquired from the Put Holder his 40% equity shares in Possehl. Upon the execution of the agreement, the puttable instrument was terminated. The purchase price consisted of 509,820 common shares of MFC Bancorp (which would be delivered upon occurrence of an event (as defined in the agreement, the latest being in 2025) and a contingent purchase price whereby 50,000 common shares of MFC Bancorp would be issued to the Put Holder for each year from 2014 to 2025 if Possehl achieves an annual net income milestone as computed under IFRS for the year. The fair values of the 509,820 common shares of MFC Bancorp and the contingent purchase price were measured at $2,736 in aggregate on the execution date of the share purchase agreement, using a generally accepted financial valuation model which took into consideration the illiquidity and restrictions of the shares, the expected timing of the triggering events, the probability of the issuance of the contingently issuable shares and appropriate discount rates. As a result, the carrying amount of the puttable instrument financial liabilities of&#8201; $4,510 were derecognized and a credit of&#8201; $3,177 was recognized in retained earnings directly. In May&nbsp;2014, the Put Holder was appointed by the Board of Directors as the President and Chief Executive Officer of MFC Bancorp.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22.72PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:30.62PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4.36PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	125
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage136"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:596.6PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">

	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:48.82PT;HEIGHT:710.23PT;MARGIN-LEFT:71.02PT;WIDTH:454.55PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	MFC BANCORP LTD.
<BR>
	(FORMERLY MFC INDUSTRIAL LTD.)
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<BR>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
<BR>
	DECEMBER 31, 2015
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 25.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions&#8201;(continued)
<BR>
	&#8199;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:1PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In June&nbsp;2014, the share purchase agreement was amended whereby the 509,820 common shares of MFC Bancorp were released to the Put Holder following the approval of the New York Stock Exchange (which was received in June&nbsp;2014) and the contingent purchase price was reduced to be payable for each year from 2014 to 2024. All other terms remain unchanged. No credit or charge was recognized in connection with these amendments.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In June&nbsp;2015, the Company issued 50,000 common shares of MFC Bancorp to its President/Chief Executive Officer as the 2014 annual net income milestone of a subsidiary was achieved.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In addition to the transactions above, the Group had the following transactions with related parties:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In April&nbsp;2014, the then-President of the Company surrendered his options to purchase 200,000 MFC Bancorp common shares at an exercise price of US$7.81 per share. The cancellation of these options had no impact on the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In February&nbsp;2013, the Group sold its interest in a group to a director of two of the Group&#8217;s sub-subsidiaries, resulting in non-cash accounting gain on securities of&#8201; $427 on disposition. The director resigned from the subsidiaries in March&nbsp;2013. In addition, a subsidiary sold its office furniture and equipment to a company beneficially owned by the Chairman of the Company for $14, resulting in a gain of&#8201; $14. Included in other receivables was an overpayment of net director fee of&#8201; $8 which was subsequently repaid by the director in 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
<FONT STYLE=" TEXT-DECORATION:UNDERLINE;">

</FONT>
</DIV>

	The Group&#8217;s key management personnel comprise the members of its Board of Directors, President, Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer. The remuneration of key management personnel of the Group was as follows:
</DIV>

	The termination benefits in 2014 represented amounts paid to the former President of the Company.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Note 26.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Instruments
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY; WIDTH:454.55PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The disclosures and analyses in this Note 26 do not include the financial instruments classified as assets held for sale and their related revenues and expenses presented (or represented) in discontinued operations.

	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:3PT 0PT 1PT 0PT; MIN-WIDTH:26.25PT; TEXT-ALIGN:RIGHT; WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	3,539
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;PADDING-LEFT:4.045PT;WIDTH:0PT;">
